title: U.S. Consumer Confidence Drops in September
text:
By Likhitha Butchireddygari

WASHINGTON--Consumer confidence dropped for a second-straight month in September, as concerns of a global economic slowdown and trade tensions weighed on consumers.

-The Conference Board, a private research group, said Tuesday its index of consumer confidence decreased to 125.1 in September, down from 134.2 in August. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had expected the index to fall to 133.0 in September.

-An index tracking expectations for the future fell to 95.8 from 106.4 last month.

-A measure of household views about the current economic situation fell to 169.0 in September from 176.0 in the prior month.

Write to Likhitha Butchireddygari at likhitha.butchireddygari@wsj.com

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 24, 2019 10:22 ET (14:22 GMT)
